docs.title: The TRACK Algorithm
docs.text: TRACK is an automated feature-tracking algorithm developed by Dr. Kevin Hodges at the University of Reading (UK). The codebase combines C and Fortran, and is compatible with most Linux-based systems using the Bash shell.

docs.title: 🔍 Main Features
docs.text:
• Tracks features based on vorticity, pressure, or other fields
  • Custom thresholds for intensity, displacement, and lifetime
  • Outputs detailed track files and summary statistics
  • Includes spatial kernel estimators and lifecycle compositing tools

TRACK has been widely used for analyzing tropical cyclones, extratropical cyclones, cut-off lows, and other synoptic-scale systems. It identifies and tracks meteorological and oceanic features—such as vorticity centers or sea-level pressure—based on user-defined criteria.

This tool enables the processing of large datasets, applicable to both reanalysis and model simulations (including present-day climate simulations and future projections). It offers flexibility for customization and produces a range of outputs, including track density maps, intensity distributions, and composite structure and lifecycle.

Version compatibility

This guide was written for TRACK version 1.5.2. Input formats and configuration details may differ across versions. Refer to version-specific documentation or contact the developer for the most accurate information.

About this documentation

This guide is based on personal communications with Dr. Hodges and reflects my interpretation of the TRACK algorithm. If you notice any errors or have suggestions, please use the form below. Include your email so I can respond.

docs.title: Calculation of Additional Fields
docs.text:
Additional Track File Attributes

You can append one or more fields to the tracks, provided that the data are on the same grid as the original dataset and maintain the same format (i.e., matching time steps and periods). Several sampling methods are available for adding new data to the tracks:

  • Input 0 → Basic interpolation (max/min at feature points)
  • Input 1 → Area averages or variance
  • Input 2 → Regional radial or lat-lng values
  • Input 3 → Sampling at fixed locations

docs.title: Area Average
docs.text:
Area averaging is commonly used for precipitation, as it ensures that a sufficient area is covered to represent the storm-associated rainfall. When using this method, you need to specify outer and inner search distances, which define the maximum range over which the algorithm will compute the new average value.

For example, in the input file below, the outer and inner values are set to 6.0° and 5.0°, respectively. You can also sample values at a point offset from the actual track feature (e.g., vorticity or MSLP).

➕ Download add_prec_era5.in

The added field can be scaled as needed. In the example, precipitation values are scaled by 3600. This conversion accounts for the fact that ERA5 total precipitation data are provided in kg m⁻² s⁻¹, which must be multiplied by 3600 to convert to mm per hour.

To calculate additional fields, use the following command:

bin/track.linux < add_prec_era5.in

This will append precipitation data to the tracks based on the configurations defined in the input file, and an output file will be created in the output directory named ff_trs.linux_addfld, which should be renamed accordingly.

docs.title: Basic Interpolation
docs.text:
When using basic interpolation (input 0), you need to choose how values are sampled relative to the feature point, which can be:

  • At the feature point (input 0)
  • Minimum (input -1)
  • Maximum (input 1)

Additionally, you have to select the search method for extrema:

  • Spline interpolation with steepest ascent/descent (input 0)
  • General search (input 1)

Finally, you must specify outer and inner search distances, similar to area averaging. The syntax is the same as that used for area average.

Note: The add_prec_era5.in file is specifically designed for ERA5 reanalysis data and should be adjusted accordingly when working with other datasets. Before running the full process, it's strongly recommended to test the configuration manually to ensure it behaves as expected. To do this, execute the following command:

bin/track.linux

You will then be prompted to enter each line of the configuration interactively, which helps ensure all values are correctly set for your dataset.

docs.title: Cyclone Spatial Structure Composites
docs.text:
🌍 Synoptic-Scale Composites of Cyclonic Systems

To investigate the synoptic-scale structure of weather systems such as cyclones, horizontal and vertical composites can be constructed using the methodology outlined by Catto et al. (2010, Journal of Climate). These spatial composites can be computed on pressure or potential temperature surfaces, or for single level fields (e.g., mean sea level pressure or precipitation). Vertical cross-sections through different cyclone features are also supported.

Composites can be generated for the time of maximum intensity based on a selected metric, or at time steps offset from this peak—allowing you to examine both the development and decay phases of the system.

docs.title: 🛠️ Step 1: Generate Additional Fields
docs.text:
Start by calculating additional field values around each cyclone. Fields can be sampled using either:

  • A radial grid, centered on the North Pole, with a prescribed radius (e.g., 15° or 20°), or
  • A rotated rectangular lat-lng grid, centered on the system and aligned with the equator

If using the rectangular grid method, specify:

  • Grid spacing (e.g., 0.5°)
  • Number of points (e.g., 100 in both directions)

Optionally, the grid can be rotated to align with the direction of cyclone motion, allowing to compute composites based on system-relative winds.

To extract a field such as mean sea level pressure (MSLP) around each system, use:

bin/track.linux < add_mslp_era5.in

This will produce a file named ff_trs.linux_addfld_reg in the outdat directory. Rename the output (e.g., reg_MSLP_MAM1979) to avoid overwriting files when repeating the process across seasons or years.

📥 Download add_mslp_era5.in

docs.title: 🧩 Step 2: Combine Seasonal/Yearly Files
docs.text:
After generating all individual reg files (e.g., 168 for 42 years × 4 seasons), merge them into a single file:

utils/bin/combine_reg < combine_reg.in

This merges multiple seasonal files into one (e.g., combined_reg), which should be renamed (e.g., reg_MSLP_ERA5) for clarity.

📥 Download combine_reg.in

docs.title: 🌀 Step 3: Generate Composite Fields
docs.text:
Use the tcident tool to compute composite fields:

utils/bin/tcident < tcident.in

You can generate composites at:

  • Time of maximum or minimum intensity
  • Time of intensity tendency extrema
  • Maximum vertical gradient
  • A specific time step in the cyclone lifecycle

You may define your own reference variable (e.g., vorticity or MSLP), though a default is typically used.

📥 Download tcident.in

Output: A NetCDF file containing composite fields will be created in the same directory as the reg files.

docs.title: 📈 Example Output
docs.text:
Figure 3

Figure 3. Composite mean sea level pressure (MSLP) for cyclonic systems in the Southern Hemisphere, centered on the time of maximum T42 850-hPa vorticity, obtained from ERA5 data.

📚 Reference: Catto et al. (2010), Can climate models capture the structure of extratropical cyclones?. Journal of Climate, 23(7), 1621–1635.

docs.title: Filtering Tracks
docs.text:
After generating cyclone tracks, you may want to filter them based on their intensity, duration or traveled distance—without modifying the RSPLICE.in file or rerunning the full tracking process. This can be accomplished using the track.linux executable.

To filter tracks based on system strength, use the following command and example:

bin/track.linux < filter.in

docs.title: Example Input File
docs.text:
📄 Download filter.in

The input file should follow this structure:

Parameter Description gridT42.utf Dummy grid file required to meet the input format. track_file Original track file to be filtered. min_value Minimum system intensity (e.g., vorticity) during the lifecycle. Higher values filter out weaker systems. max_value Maximum allowed system intensity. Set a high value (e.g., 100000) to avoid exclusions. min_lifetime Minimum track duration, in time steps or real-time format (e.g., YYYYMMDD). For 6-hourly data, min_lifetime = 8 retains tracks longer than 48 hours. max_lifetime Maximum track duration. Use a large value if you do not wish to apply an upper limit.

You can apply a similar filtering approach for traveled distance, measured in geodesic degrees (1 deg ≈ 111 km per degree).

docs.title: Installation procedure
docs.text: To configure and install the TRACK code, the following software are needed:

docs.title: Required software
docs.text:
1. gcc compiler
  2. gfortran compiler
  3. NetCDF (Network Common Data Form) software libraries

docs.title: Optional but strongly recommended
docs.text:
1. CDO – Climate Data Operators for managing NetCDF files
  2. NCO – NetCDF Operators for managing NetCDF files
  3. GrADS or another visualization tool

docs.title: Step 1 – Go to the TRACK directory
docs.text:
Navigate to the installation folder:

cd TRACK-1.5.2

Ensure the current directory . is in your PATH environment variable:

export PATH=${PATH}:.

docs.title: Step 2 – Set environment variables (bash)
docs.text:
In bash, export the following variables:

export CC=gcc
export FC=gfortran
export ARFLAGS=
export NETCDF=[path_to_your_netcdf_installation]

Replace [path_to_your_netcdf_installation] with the actual location of your NetCDF installation.

docs.title: Step 3 – Build the main executable
docs.text:
Use the following command to build the executable (you can change linux to another name if desired):

master -build -i=linux -f=linux

docs.title: Step 4 – Compile utility functions
docs.text:
Run the following to compile the utility programs:

make utils

docs.title: Step 5 – Optional: Install in a custom directory
docs.text:
If you want to install the code outside of your $HOME directory, use:

master -build -i=linux -f=linux -u=[path]

Replace [path] with the directory path where the TRACK directory is located.

docs.title: Final step – verify installation
docs.text:
If everything is correctly configured, the executable track.linux will be created in the bin/ directory.

✅ You are now ready to run the TRACK code!

docs.title: ♻️ Temporal compositing using lifecycle utility
docs.text: The algorithm performs compositing of atmospheric fields at different stages of a system’s life cycle relative to its time of maximum intensity (e.g., peak 850-hPa relative vorticity). This method allows analysis of the temporal evolution of weather systems by averaging selected variables over multiple cases.

docs.title: How it works:
docs.text:
• Required fields (e.g., mean sea level pressure, temperature, precipitation) must be previously added to the track files.

➡️ See the Calculation of Additional Fields section for more details on how to add fields to the tracks.

• These values are interpolated onto a radial grid centered on the system, using a prescribed radius (commonly 15° or 20°).

• A subset of tracks is usually selected for compositing (e.g., top 10% most intense systems, based on a chosen metric).

• For each track, the algorithm extracts the chosen fields at multiple time steps before and after the peak intensity.

• These field values are then averaged across all selected tracks to generate a composite life cycle view.

docs.title: Key points:
docs.text:
✓ Individual cases retain mesoscale structures.

✓ Composite fields reveal common features but smooth out finer details (e.g., fronts).

✓ Uncertainty can be estimated from the standard deviation across all cases.

⚠️ Note: While the method allows wide time windows around the peak, this may introduce noise due to variability in system lifetimes. → To minimize this, restrict the analysis to systems with a minimum lifetime threshold.

docs.title: How to run:
docs.text:
Use the following command:

utils/bin/lifecycle < lifecycle.in

📥 Download lifecycle.in Use this version for track files without additional fields.

📥 Download lifecycle_addflds.in Use this version for track files with additional fields.

→ Replace Field in the input file with the number corresponding to the field you want to composite (use 0 for the default reference field).

docs.title: Output:
docs.text: The algorithm writes results to history.dat, containing the mean value of the selected field at each timestep relative to the system’s peak intensity.

docs.title: Visualization:
docs.text:
The figure below shows an example of the composite life cycle of winter cyclones in the Southern Hemisphere, based on T42 850-hPa relative vorticity.

Figure 1

Figure 1. Life cycle composite of all cyclonic systems identified using 850-hPa vorticity in the Southern Hemisphere. Field shown is T42-resolution 850-hPa vorticity, centered at the time of maximum intensity. Based on ERA5 data (1979–2020), computed from 16,998 tracks.

docs.title: Preparing Input Data
docs.text:
Preparing Input Data

Before running the TRACK algorithm, make sure to download the required global dataset to your local disk storage. The code only supports input data in NetCDF format.

⚠️ File format requirement Gridded binary data must be converted to NetCDF before using it with the TRACK code.

docs.title: ⏱️ Data Frequency
docs.text: TRACK performs tracking typically using 6-hourly data, applied to fields such as Vorticity and Mean Sea Level Pressure (MSLP)

docs.title: 📂 Organization of Input Files
docs.text: For climatological analysis, input data are usually grouped by Month, Season, or Year

docs.title: 📁 Example
docs.text:
ERA5_U850_MAM1979.nc  →  (368 time steps)

This refers to 6-hourly 850-hPa zonal wind from ERA5 reanalysis, covering the period from 1 March 1979 to 31 May 1979.

ℹ️ Dataset compatibility Although this guide uses ERA5 reanalysis as the example, the TRACK algorithm is compatible with other datasets as long as they follow the required format.

docs.title: 📌 File Location
docs.text:
All input files must be placed in the indat directory of your TRACK installation.

To avoid using too much space in your home directory, it is recommended to create a symbolic link to your actual data location:

ln -s [path_to_your_data]/ERA5_U850_MAM1979.nc /home/user/TRACK-1.5.2/indat/ERA5_U850_MAM1979.nc

Replace [path_to_your_data] with the actual path where your NetCDF files are stored.

docs.title: Terminology
docs.text:
Throughout the documentation and release notes, the following terms are commonly used:

  • Feature point: An individual point along a track, representing its position and properties at a given time step.

  • Track file: A text file containing information about one or more tracked features, including their positions, intensities, and durations.

  • Main directory: The root path where the TRACK algorithm is installed or executed (e.g., /home/user/TRACK-1.5.2).

docs.title: Common Errors and Solutions
docs.text: 🛠️ Troubleshooting

docs.title: 1. Fixing Segmentation Fault in track.linux
docs.text:
If running any task using:

bin/track.linux

results in a crash with the message "Segmentation fault", it's likely due to a shell-related issue.

Solution: To resolve it, increase the stack size limit:

ulimit -s unlimited

Then rerun the command.

docs.title: 2. Resolving the Master Lock File Issue
docs.text:
If you encounter the following message:

A master lock file has been detected, possible causes:
     (a) The master shell script is currently running.
     (b) A redundant lock file exists due to an aborted master script.
Do you want to reset the lock or wait for it to be released?
         0 ----  wait.
         1 ----  reset.
Waiting for the master lock to be released.

Solution: This is likely due to leftover .master.lock files. List and remove them:

ls -al .master.lock*
rm .master.lock*

After this, the program should run normally.

docs.title: 3. Resolving Incorrect Tracking and Vorticity Scaling
docs.text:
If output shows unrealistic or constant vorticity values like:

1 202.724106 -10.558068 7.706274e+16 
2 202.724106 -10.558068 7.706274e+16 
...

Solution: This typically means there are missing values in the U and V wind fields. Use a visualization tool like xconv (available in the converters/ directory) to inspect your data.

If missing values are found, fill them with:

cdo fillmiss infile outfile

This should correct the issue and ensure proper tracking and intensity scaling.

docs.title: 4. Disabling rsh in the Master Script
docs.text:
If you are prompted for a password when running the TRACK master script, it's because rsh is enabled. To disable it:

Step 1: Edit the master script. Find this line:

RSH="rsh -n"

Replace it with:

RSH="norsh"

Step 2: Modify NORSH assignment logic. Replace this block:

rsh $HOST ls >> /dev/null
if [ $? != 0 ]
then
   echo "no working rsh to $HOST using job submission to current machine without rsh"
   NORSH="norsh"
else
   echo "Have working rsh to $HOST"
   NORSH="rsh"
fi

with:

# Disable rsh checks and force "norsh" mode
NORSH="norsh"

This prevents rsh prompts and forces job submission in "norsh" mode.

docs.title: Utility Programs
docs.text:
Track Processing Utilities: Box / Count / Censemble2

The TRACK algorithm provides a range of utilities for post-processing trajectories, including:

  • Spatial and temporal domain selection
  • Track comparison between different datasets
  • Frequency distributions of intensity and associated variables (e.g., area-averaged precipitation)

These tools are located in the utils directory.

docs.title: 📦 Box: Select trajectories within a latitude-longitude domain
docs.text:
utils/bin/box [filename] [Lat1] [Lat2] [Lng1] [Lng2] [Genesis (0)/Lysis (1)/Passing (2)/Passing Time (3)/All Times (4)] [Negate (1)] [Track Thresh] [Start Time, YYYYMMDDHH]
  • Lat1, Lat2: southernmost and northernmost latitude bounds
  • Lng1, Lng2: westernmost and easternmost longitude bounds

Example:

utils/bin/box track_file -60 -40 280 330 0 0

This command generates a new file in the same directory as the original, with the extension .new. The output will contain only the tracks that originated within the specified domain: latitudes between -60° and -40°, and longitudes between 280° and 330°.

docs.title: 🧭 Count: Select trajectories within a spherical region
docs.text:
utils/bin/count [filename] [Lat.] [Lng.] [Radius] [Genesis (0)/Lysis (1)/Passing (2)/Passing Time (3)/All Times (4)] [Negate (1)] [Start Time, YYYYMMDDHH] [Timestep]

This command filters tracks to retain only those whose genesis points lie within a spherical cap (defined in geodesic degrees).

Example:

utils/bin/count track_file -35.0 280.0 8.0 0 0

This selects tracks that originated within a circular region of 8 degrees radius, centered at 35°S, 80°W. The output file, named with a .new extension, will be saved in the same directory.

docs.title: ⏱ Time Conversion
docs.text:
The count command supports converting time steps into real-time format (e.g., YYYYMMDD). Use the following syntax:

utils/bin/count track_file 0 0 5 4 0 1979030100 6
  • 1979030100: reference start time
  • 6: time step (in hours)

docs.title: 🔬 Censemble2: Advanced filtering and comparison of tracks
docs.text:
censemble2 [track_file1] [track_file2] [temp1] [temp2] [nbin] [mean (0), max (1) or min (2) intensity : offset] \
[Mean (0) or Min (1) separation : use whole track (0) or start of track (1)] [format of main distributions #/month (0), frequency (1), pdf (2)] \
[Add. field Id. 1: location : time sample] [Add. field Id. 1 : use location (0 or 1) : use time sampling] \ [Add. field Id. 2 : use location : use time sampling]
[Ftype: 's' or 'vn', n=0 (speed), n=1 (tendency), n=2 (growth)] [Region matching type, '-1' (no region matching), '0' (track in region), '1' (extrema in region), '2' (60% of points in region),'3' (extrema of region)] \
[Re-order tracks, '1' for yes or '0' for no] [Dist. Thresh. (optional)] [Time. Thresh. (optional)][Intensity Range, I1, I2 (optional)]

docs.title: 📊 Frequency Distribution
docs.text:
The censemble2 utility is used to generate frequency distributions of any variable present in the track file which will be displayed on the prompt. Below is an example command and a breakdown of its syntax:

utils/bin/censemble2 track_file track_file 0 28 10 1 0 1 0 0 s -1

Explanation of each argument (in order):

First term (track_file): Input track file.

Second term (track_file): The same track file must be provided again.

Third term (0): Minimum value of the intensity range (e.g., minimum vorticity).

Fourth term (28): Maximum value of the intensity range.

  • ⚠️ If a track exceeds this range, you’ll see:
***ERROR***, strength outside range for a track number

Fifth term (10): Number of bins for the frequency distribution.

Sixth term (1): Statistic used for intensity:

  • 0 = Mean
  • 1 = Maximum
  • 2 = Minimum

Seventh term (0): Mean or minimum separation distance (used for matching tracks).

Eighth term (1): Distribution format (month, frequency, or PDF).

Ninth and Tenth term (0): Field selection flag (used if there are additional fields). Set both ninth and tenth terms to 0 if not using extra fields.

Eleventh term (s): Smoothing option. Use s for standard smoothing.

Twelfth term (-1): Region matching type:

  • -1 = No region.dat used
  • Positive integers refer to region groupings in region.dat if used

docs.title: 📍 Region and Time Selection
docs.text:
utils/bin/censemble2 track_file track_file 0 1000 10 0 0 0 0 0 s 2 0

Requires a file named region.dat in the same directory. 📥 Download region.dat

Using the example input file, select tracks where longitude spans 280°–350° and latitude spans -45° to -20°, with ≥60% of their points falling within this region, and where the time range (for time step) is between 1 and 1,000,000.

⚠️ Warning: Remove region.dat after use to avoid unintended filtering.

docs.title: 🌪 Extracting Maximum Intensity Locations
docs.text:
Use the str.dat file generated by the Censemble2 to extract maximum intensity location. Example for 95th percentile:

awk '{print $9}' str.dat | sort -n | awk '{all[NR] = $0} END{print all[int(NR*0.95 - 0.5)]}'

docs.title: 🔁 Matching Tracks Between Datasets
docs.text:
To match the same systems between two datasets (e.g., vorticity and MSLP):

utils/bin/censemble2 track_file1 track_file2 0 1000 10 1 0 0 0 0 s -1 4.0 0.5
  • 4.0: max displacement (deg)
  • 0.5: minimum percent of overlapping points (50%)

Latitude/longitude will follow the first track file.

To compute the mean separation distance, reverse the files and run the command again:

utils/bin/censemble2 [track_file2] [track_file1] 0 1000 10 1 0 0 0 0 s -1 4.0 0.5

📚 Reference: Hodges et al. (2003), Monthly Weather Review, 131(9), 2012–2037.

docs.title: Visualizing Tracks and Track Density
docs.text:
Figure 1a presents the 456 tracks identified in ERA5 for the Southern Hemisphere (March–May 1979), restricted to the tracks with a displacement distance of at least 1,000 km and a duration of 48 hours (8 consecutive time steps), as defined in the RSPLICE.in file.

Figure 1b illustrates the track density, computed using the track point closest to each estimation location, normalized to tracks per season per 5° spherical cap (approximately 10⁶ km²).

Figure 1

Figure 1. (a) Trajectories of all cyclonic systems identified in the 850-hPa vorticity in the Southern Hemisphere. (b) Track density (shaded) for the same systems, where the unit is number per season per unit area (≅ 10⁶ km²). Statistics are produced using ERA5 data for the period March–May 1979.

docs.title: Running the Code
docs.text:
This section provides a detailed guide on how to run the TRACK algorithm from start to finish. The process includes customizing configuration files, preparing input fields, executing the core routines, and post-processing outputs.

Whether you are tracking extratropical cyclones, cut-off lows, or tropical systems, TRACK offers flexibility through modular steps and adjustable parameters. You can run the full workflow or focus on specific components depending on your needs.

Figure 1. Overview of the TRACK processing workflow.

docs.title: Subsections
docs.text:
👉 Click below to explore each step:

  • Customizing Track Displacement and Smoothing
  • Configuring RSPLICE and RUNDATIN Files
  • Calculating Vorticity
  • Data Pre-processing
  • Producing Track Files with the Master Executable
  • Running All Steps Automatically
  • Combining Track Files and Producing Spatial Fields with Kernel Estimators

⚙️ You don’t need to run every step manually — TRACK allows automation of the entire pipeline!

For advanced usage and troubleshooting tips, continue exploring the rest of the guide.

docs.title: Executing All Steps in One Go
docs.text:
Note

Once all the previous steps are executed correctly, you can use a script to run them automatically, which is useful for creating climatologies.

Use the following syntax:

trackrun_ERA5.csh MAM 1979

This command will create track files for both hemispheres for the March, April, and May (MAM) period of the year 1979.

Below is an example of a script to execute all steps automatically. Note that the line referring to Cholesky is commented out because it should only be run once.

➕ Download trackrun_ERA5.csh

docs.title: Data Pre-processing
docs.text:
Data Pre-processing

After generating the vorticity data, this step prepares it for spectral filtering and spectral truncation.

The data are initially truncated to a triangular truncation on a Gaussian grid, focusing on synoptic-scale features. - Vorticity fields: typically truncated at T42, as this is a noisy variable. - MSLP or geopotential height fields: may use T63 or T106.

The large-scale background is removed using spherical harmonic decomposition, setting coefficients of wavenumbers ≤ 5 to zero.

docs.title: 🔧 Running Cholesky Pre-processing
docs.text:
This operation uses the configuration file cholesky_ERA5.in, located in the main directory. It needs to be run only once, although the process may take some time.

bin/track.linux -i ERA5_VOR850_MAM1979.dat -f chol < cholesky_ERA5.in

Alternatively, to answer the prompts manually, run:

bin/track.linux -i ERA5_VOR850_MAM1979.dat -f chol

➕ Download cholesky_ERA5.in

Grid Size Example

1440 and 719
These values in the cholesky_ERA5.in file correspond to the X and Y grid dimensions, excluding the poles (i.e., 721 - 2 = 719 in the Y direction).

docs.title: 📤 Output Files from Cholesky
docs.text:
• A binary file named specfil.chol_band000 will be created in the outdat/ directory.
  • Another file will be saved in the spectral/ directory, named based on the last line in the input file. E.g., ERA5-T42-1440-719.

You may use a custom filename for the input file, but the command syntax must remain the same.

docs.title: 🌐 Running Spectral Filtering
docs.text:
Next, perform spectral filtering using the following command:

bin/track.linux -i ERA5_VOR850_MAM1979.dat -f filt < specfilt_ERA5.in

➕ Download specfilt_ERA5.in

Don't worry about warnings

You may see error messages during execution — these are expected and not a problem.

docs.title: 📤 Output File
docs.text:
After filtering, a binary file named:

specfil.filt_band000

...will be created in the outdat/ directory.

Move this file to the indat/ directory and rename it (e.g., ERA5_VOR850_MAM1979_filt.dat). This will be your vorticity data truncated at T42 resolution, ready for feature tracking.

docs.title: Producing Track Files with the Master Executable
docs.text:
Producing Track Files with the Master Executable

Once the pre-processed vorticity data is ready, you can generate the track files using the master script. This step requires careful attention to the syntax:

master -c=VOR850_MAM1979_T42 -d=now -e=track.linux -i=ERA5_VOR850_MAM1979_filt.dat -f=MAM1979 -n=1,32,12 -o={path_where_the_track_files_will_be_produced} -j=RUN_AT.in -r=RUN_AT_ -s=RUNDATIN.ERA5_VOR

Here's a breakdown of the options:

  • -c=: Name of the directory that will contain the output files
  • -d=: Stores current date and time (use now)
  • -e=: Name of the main executable (e.g., track.linux)
  • -i=: Input data file (produced in the previous filtering step)
  • -f=: Label for the run (e.g., MAM1979)
  • -n=: Time settings (e.g., 1,32,12 for seasonal analysis:
  • 1: Start time
  • 32: Approximate days per month
  • 12: Total time steps (3 months × 4 time steps/day))
  • -o=: Output path where track files will be saved
  • -j=: Syntax file for run control (e.g., RUN_AT.in)
  • -r=: Run name prefix (e.g., RUN_AT_)
  • -s=: Input file for controlling intensity threshold (e.g., RUNDATIN.ERA5_VOR)

docs.title: 📄 Output Files
docs.text:
The code creates text files with information on the location (longitude and latitude) and intensity for each track at each time step in radial coordinates.

By default, it produces the following compressed files:

  • tr_trs_neg and tr_trs_pos: Contain all identified tracks for the Southern and Northern Hemispheres, respectively. Each track includes the sequence of feature points that meet the vorticity (or MSLP) threshold.

  • ff_trs_neg and ff_trs_pos: Filtered versions of the above, excluding tracks that don't meet the criteria set in RSPLICE.in for minimum lifetime and travel distance.

Note: - The suffix "neg" indicates Southern Hemisphere tracks. - The suffix "pos" indicates Northern Hemisphere tracks.

On average, generating the output track files for one season and one year may require approximately 3.5 MB, depending on resolution.

docs.title: 📘 Example Output Format
docs.text:
0
0 0
TRACK_NUM 1148 ADD_FLD 0 0 &
TRACK_ID 3
POINT_NUM 6
1 231.915375 -16.565212 2.238685e+00
2 231.581451 -18.106936 1.992483e+00
3 230.683823 -18.975389 1.859596e+00
4 230.880386 -18.826279 2.329082e+00
5 231.136749 -19.203224 2.855023e+00
6 231.395935 -20.242941 1.929559e+00
...

This means: - TRACK_NUM: There are 1148 tracks - TRACK_ID: The reference number of the track (e.g., 3) - POINT_NUM: Number of points in the track (e.g., 6 time steps = 36 hours lifetime)

Columns in each point line:

  1. Timestep
  2. Longitude
  3. Latitude
  4. Intensity (e.g., T42 850-hPa relative vorticity, scaled by -1.0 × 10⁻⁵ s⁻¹ for SH)

docs.title: Input Configuration Files
docs.text:
RSPLICE.in file

If you plan to track cyclones, you must define parameters that control the intensity, lifetime, and displacement distance of the tracked features.

Open the RSPLICE.in file located in the indat/ directory and adjust the values according to your analysis setup.

⚠️ Important: Ensure there is no blank line at the end of the file.

Example content of RSPLICE.in:

n
1
initial
y
1
n
1
12!
n
8              # Retains tracks lasting longer than 8 time steps (e.g., 48 hours if data is 6-hourly).
1000000        # Upper bound to retain extremely long-lived tracks (usually left as-is).
y              # Enables filtering by displacement distance.
10.0           # Minimum distance a system must travel (in degrees; 10° ≈ 1000 km).
s             
n
n
n
a
n
n
n
0

Note: The # symbol is used here to indicate comments for clarity and should not appear in your actual file.

➕ Download RSPLICE.in

RUNDATIN and initial.T42_ files

The RUNDATIN.ERA5_VOR.in and RUNDATIN.ERA5_VOR_A.in files are input configuration files used to define the intensity threshold applied to the filtered vorticity field.

These thresholds control which features are retained for tracking—only those above (or below) the defined threshold will be considered.

  • RUNDATIN.ERA5_VOR.in: typically used for tracking cyclones in the Northern Hemisphere
  • RUNDATIN.ERA5_VOR_A.in: typically used for tracking cyclones in the Southern Hemisphere

These files also specify scaling parameters and the threshold value, which are usually found on line 8 of the file.

⚠️ Note: Line numbers may vary depending on the dataset and the version of the tracking code.

Threshold example

1.0e+5
This value corresponds to a vorticity threshold of 1.0 × 10⁻⁵ s⁻¹ in the filtered field.

Additionally, the files initial.T42_NH and initial.T42_SH must be present in the data/ directory. These files are required for initializing cyclone tracking in each respective hemisphere.

docs.title: Combining Tracks and Producing Spatial Field Estimation
docs.text:
Combining Track Files and Producing Spatial Fields with Kernel Estimators

Spatial statistics are produced from the tracks using spherical kernel estimators (Hodges 1996). Tracks are first grouped by months or seasons using the combine utility, located in the utils directory. Seasons follow the standard meteorological definitions: DJF (December–February), MAM (March–May), JJA (June–August), and SON (September–November). The combine utility merges track files for a given season across multiple years, creating a single file representing the entire period. For example, all track files for MAM across available years are combined to compute a seasonal mean.

To combine track files, run the following command in the main directory:

utils/bin/combine < combine.in

This generates an output file called (combined_tr_trs) which should be renamed accordingly (e.g., tr_trs_ERA5_MAM1979-2020). Repeat this process for each season.

Example combine.in file:

42
1
/path_to_the_track_files/ff_trs_MAM1979
/path_to_the_track_files/ff_trs_MAM1980
. . .
/path_to_the_track_files/ff_trs_MAM2020

The first line specifies the number of track files to combine (42 in this case). The second line defines the time scaling:

  • 1 = Seasonal
  • 2 = Monthly
  • 3 = Daily

Since we are working with seasonal data, we use 1.

The next step is to generate the spatial statistics using the bb_stats.job executable. Before running this, ensure that the all_pr_in file is present in the same directory as the track files.

Example all_pr_in file:

#!/bin/csh
set FIELD = $1
set DIR=$2
set BASE=$3
set VAR=tr_trs_$FIELD
set STUB=$FIELD
if( ! -e ${DIR}/STATOUT_$STUB) then
   run_stats -c=$DIR -d=STATS.latlng.in -e=track.linux -f=era -i=tr_trs_$STUB -o=${BASE}
endif

This script calls a file named STATS.latlng.in, which must be located in the indat directory.

➕ Download STATS.latlng.in

If the spatial statistics are generated from track files with additional fields, use the following input file and adjust the all_pr_in file accordingly.

➕ Download STATS.latlng_addfld.in

➕ Download gridT42.utf

Once the required files are in place, run the following command in the main directory:

bb_stats.job track_file[without tr_trs_] subdirectory path

For example, if the track file produced in the previous step is stored in /media/user/TRACKS, use:

bb_stats.job ERA5_MAM1979-2020 TRACKS /media/user

This process may take some time, depending on the file size and available computational resources.

The output will be a NetCDF file named:

stat_trs_scl_ERA5_MAM1979-2020_1.nc

This file will be located in the same directory as the track file. However, certain software (e.g., GrADS) may not be able to read the file directly. If needed, you can reformat it using the Climate Data Operators (CDO) tool with the following command:

cdo -f nc copy stat_trs_scl_ERA5_MAM1979-2020_1.nc stat_trs_scl_ERA5_MAM1979-2020_new_file.nc

This process generates a NetCDF file containing various spatial statistical fields, as shown below. The file has an X-Y dimension with a fixed resolution of 128 points in X and 64 points in Y, regardless of the original data resolution used to produce the trajectories. This ensures easier comparison between datasets of different resolutions.

Spatial Statistical Fields:

  • mstr = Mean Intensity
  • stdstr = Std of Intensity
  • msp = Mean Speed
  • stdsp = Std of Speed
  • fden = Feature Density
  • gden = Genesis Density
  • lden = Lysis Density
  • tden = Track Density
  • xvel = X-component of Mean Velocity
  • yvel = Y-component of Mean Velocity
  • mlif = Mean Lifetime
  • mgdr = Mean Growth/Decay Rate
  • miso = Mean Anisotropy
  • xor = X-component of Mean Orientation Vector
  • yor = Y-component of Mean Orientation Vector
  • mten = Mean Tendency
  • marea = Mean Area
  • spare1 = Spare1
  • spare2 = Spare2

📚 References - Hodges, K. I. (1996). Spherical nonparametric estimators applied to the UGAMP model integration for AMIP. Monthly Weather Review, 124(12), 2914–2932. https://doi.org/10.1175/1520-0493(1996)124<2914:SNEATT>2.0.CO;2

docs.title: Customizing Track Displacement and Smoothing
docs.text:
The files zone.dat0 and adapt.dat0 define the regional displacement constraints and track smoothness used by the tracking algorithm. These files reside in the data/ directory and are configured by default to detect mid-latitude (extratropical) cyclones.

To adapt the tracking for slower-moving systems (e.g., cut-off lows, tropical cyclones), or to adjust for different data temporal resolutions, you should modify these configuration files accordingly. Guidance on adjusting these parameters can be found in:

📚 References - Hodges, K. I. (1999). Adaptive constraints for feature tracking. Monthly Weather Review, 127(6), 1362–1373. https://doi.org/10.1175/1520-0493(1999)127<1362:ACFFT>2.0.CO;2 - Pinheiro, H. R., Hodges, K. I., & Gan, M. A. (2019). Sensitivity of identifying cut-off lows in the Southern Hemisphere using multiple criteria: Implications for numbers, seasonality and intensity. Climate Dynamics, 53, 6699–6713. https://doi.org/10.1007/s00382-019-04984-x

docs.title: Key Parameters
docs.text:
• In zone.dat, the last column on each line sets the maximum allowable displacement per time step (in degrees). Smaller values (e.g., 3.0) are better for tracking slow systems.
  • In adapt.dat, the second line controls the smoothness of tracks, balancing directional and speed variability. Tuning this is crucial for differentiating between sharp directional shifts and consistent movement.

docs.title: For mid-latitude cyclones:
docs.text:
• Download zone.dat
  • Download adapt.dat

docs.title: For slow-moving systems (e.g., cut-off lows, tropical cyclones):
docs.text:
• Download zone_COL.dat
  • Download adapt_COL.dat

docs.title: Using the Input Files
docs.text:
After selecting your desired configuration, create symbolic links in the data/ directory so the tracking code can locate the appropriate files:

ln -s zone.dat zone.dat0

ln -s adapt.dat adapt.dat0

docs.title: Calculating Vorticity
docs.text:
Calculating Relative Vorticity

In many cases, relative vorticity data may not be directly available—especially when working with output from numerical model simulations. In such situations, you can calculate relative vorticity from the zonal and meridional wind components using the tracking code itself.

Why calculate it yourself?

Even if you already have vorticity data, it is recommended to calculate it using the tracking code. This ensures consistency in formatting, resolution, and variable structure.

Wind data location

Before running the vorticity calculation, make sure that the zonal and meridional wind files are located in the indat/ directory, or that symbolic links to the data exist in this directory.

➡️ See the Preparing input data section for more details on how to set this up.

Command to calculate vorticity

Run the following command to calculate vorticity:

bin/track.linux < calcvor_ERA5.in

This will generate a binary file, for example:

ERA5_VOR850_MAM1979.dat

This output is then used for spectral filtering and spectral truncation in later steps.

Download input file

📄 ➕ Download calcvor_ERA5.in
